{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=September 2018}} {{short description|classification of OFCs or tax havens}} {{See also|Offshore financial centre}} {{Taxation}} [[File:Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers Figure 3 Network of ownership flows between countries.jpg|thumb|"Uncovering [[Offshore Financial Centers]]": CORPNET's map of connections between countries]] '''Conduit OFC''' and '''Sink OFC''' is an empirical quantitative method of classifying [[corporate tax haven]]s, [[offshore financial centres]] and [[tax havens]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jul/25/netherlands-and-uk-are-biggest-channels-for-corporate-tax-avoidance|title=Netherlands and UK are biggest channels for corporate tax avoidance|publisher=The Guardian|date=25 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-31/is-the-u-k-already-the-kind-of-tax-haven-it-claims-it-won-t-be|title=Is the U.K. Already the Kind of Tax Haven It Claims It Won't Be?|publisher=Bloomberg News|date=31 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-04-11/tax-havens-can-be-surprisingly-close-to-home|title=Tax Havens Can Be Surprisingly Close to Home|publisher=Bloomberg View|date=11 April 2017}} Rather than analyzing taxation and legal structures to identify and classify potential tax havens (the preferred EU, IMF, and OECD route), this approach analyses the ownership chains of 98 million global companies (a purely empirical, or outcomes–based, route), relative to the size of countries of their incorporation. The technique gives both a method of classification and a method of understanding the relative scale of corporate tax havens/offshore financial centers. The results were formally published by the University of Amsterdam's CORPNET Group in July 2017, and identify two major classifications: * 24 global Sink OFCs: jurisdictions in which a disproportional amount of value disappears from the economic system (i.e. the traditional [[tax havens]]).
(See the table below for the list of Sinks) * 5 global Conduit OFCs: jurisdictions through which a disproportional amount of value moves toward sink OFCs (i.e. modern [[corporate tax haven]]s).
(Conduits are: Netherlands, United Kingdom, Switzerland, Singapore and Ireland) {{quote|Our findings debunk the myth of tax havens{{efn|name="def"|As discussed in the ''Definitions'' sections of [[tax havens]], and of [[offshore financial centres]], most tax academics consider the terms as being synonymous and use them inter–changeably}} as exotic far–flung islands that are difficult, if not impossible, to regulate. Many offshore financial centers{{efn|name="def"}} are highly developed countries with strong regulatory environments.|author=Javier Garcia-Bernardo, Jan Fichtner, Frank W. Takes & Eelke M. Heemskerk, CORPNET [[University of Amsterdam]]}} The CORPNET report has been praised, and in March 2017, the EU has adopted its approach into some of their policy frameworks. Research by [[Gabriel Zucman]] (et alia) published in June 2018, showed using Orbis database connections, underestimates Ireland, which the [[Gabriel Zucman#Zucman-Tørsløv-Wier 2018 list|Zucman–Tørsløv–Wier 2018 list]] shows is the largest corporate Conduit OFC in the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Fireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401|title=Ireland is the world’s biggest corporate ‘tax haven’, say academics|quote=Study claims State shelters more multinational profits than the entire Caribbean|publisher=Irish Times|date=13 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporations-push-profits-into-tax-havens-as-countries-struggle-in-pursuit-study-says-1528634659|title=Zucman:Corporations Push Profits Into Corporate Tax Havens as Countries Struggle in Pursuit, Gabrial Zucman Study Says|quote=Such profit shifting leads to a total annual revenue loss of $200 billion globally|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=10 June 2018}} However, CORPNET's Conduits and Sinks, reconcile closely with the world's [[Tax havens#Top 10 tax havens|top ten tax havens]]. ==Background== {{see also|Tax haven#Tax haven lists}} [[File:Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers Cayman Conundrum.jpg|thumb|"Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers": Cayman Islands Conundrum]] The lack of an accepted [[Tax haven#Definitions|definition]] for identifying corporate tax havens/offshore financial centres, results in different lists, including: * Academic leaders in tax haven research, namely:{{cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/info/sites/info/files/dp_055_en.pdf|title=Banks in Tax Havens: First Evidence based on Country–by–Country Reporting|page=50|quote=Figure D: Tax Haven Literature Review: A Typology|publisher=[[EU Commission]]|date=July 2017}} [[James R. Hines Jr.]] (1994, 2007, 2010){{cite journal|url=https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.ie/&httpsredir=1&article=1716&context=articles|title=Treasure Islands|pages=103–125|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|quote=Table 1: 52 Tax Havens|journal=[[Journal of Economic Perspectives]]|volume=4|issue=24|date=2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bus.umich.edu/otpr/WP2007-3.pdf|title=Tax Havens|quote=There are roughly 45 major tax havens in the world today. Examples include Andorra, Ireland, Luxembourg and Monaco in Europe, Hong Kong and Singapore in Asia, and the Cayman Islands, the Netherlands Antilles, and Panama in the Americas. |author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|publisher=University of Michigan|date=2007}}{{cite journal|url=http://taxdoctoralseminar.web.unc.edu/files/2016/02/Hines-Rice.pdf|title=FISCAL PARADISE: FOREIGN TAX HAVENS AND AMERICAN BUSINESS |author1=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|author2=Eric M. Rice|quote=We identify 41 countries and regions as tax havens for the purposes of U. S. businesses. Together the seven tax havens with populations greater than one million (Hong Kong, Ireland, Liberia, Lebanon, Panama, Singapore, and Switzerland) account for 80 percent of total tax haven population and 89 percent of tax haven GDP. |journal=[[Quarterly Journal of Economics]] (Harvard/MIT)|date=February 1994|volume=9|issue=1}} [[Dhammika Dharmapala]] (2008 and 2009),{{cite journal|author1=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]]|author2=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|pages=1058–1068|volume=93 |issue=9–10| url=http://faculty.smu.edu/millimet/classes/eco6375/papers/dharmapala%20hines.pdf|title=Which countries become tax havens?|journal=[[Journal of notice| publisher=The Guardian | date=5 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/02/paradise-to-blacklist-eu-tax-havens| title=From paradise to blacklist: EU’s net starts to close on tax havens| publisher=The Guardian | date=2 December 2017}} A key difference between the lists regards the major corporate tax havens (or offshore financial centres), like Ireland the Netherlands and Luxembourg (amongst others).{{cite web|url=https://www.caymancompass.com/2017/08/01/new-study-offers-more-nuanced-look-at-offshore-finance/|title=New study offers more nuanced look at offshore finance| publisher=Cayman Compass | date=1 August 2017}} Major regulators like the EU and the OECD don't regard them as tax havens, and point to their transparency and compliance with international regulations.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/there-is-a-definition-of-a-tax-haven-and-ireland-doesnt-make-that-grade-35095264.html|title=There is a definition of a tax haven - and Ireland doesn't make that grade|publisher=Irish Independent|date=2 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/oced-ireland-tax-haven-1005122-Jul2013/|title=OECD tax chief: 'Ireland is not a tax haven'|publisher=thejournal.ie|date=23 July 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://euobserver.com/economic/140279|title=EU countries are not 'tax havens', parliament says|publisher=EU Observer|date=14 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://nltimes.nl/2017/12/06/eu-releases-tax-haven-blacklist-netherlands|title=EU RELEASES TAX HAVEN BLACKLIST; NETHERLANDS NOT ON IT|publisher=NL Times|date=6 December 2017}} Academics and other non–governmental organizations, however, point to their role in major corporate tax avoidance from [[base erosion and profit shifting]] (“BEPS”) schemes, like the [[double Irish]], the [[Double Irish arrangement#Replacement by single malt|single malt]] and the [[dutch sandwich]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/oxfam-tax-haven-3133714-Dec2016/|title=Ireland named world's 6th worst corporate tax haven|publisher=journal.ie|date=12 December 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2016/09/15/now-brazil-says-ireland-tax-haven/|title=Now Brazil puts Ireland on its tax haven blacklist|publisher=Tax Justice Network|date=17 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/oxfam-says-ireland-is-a-tax-haven-judged-by-eu-criteria-1.3307370?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Foxfam-says-ireland-is-a-tax-haven-judged-by-eu-criteria-1.3307370|title=Oxfam says Ireland is a tax haven judged by EU criteria|publisher=Irish Times|date=28 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.oxfamireland.org/sites/default/files/upload/pdfs/mantras-myths-final.pdf|title=MANTRAS AND MYTHS: A true picture of the corporate tax system in Ireland|publisher=RTE News|date=February 2017}} They regard them as major tax havens in their [[Tax haven#Definitions|definitions of tax havens]]. This disconnect regarding corporate tax havens is discussed [[Ireland as a tax haven#Political compromises|here]]. ==CORPNET Report== [[File:Offshore Financial Centre Chains.png|thumb|"Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers": Example of a corporate global ownership chain]] A report published in [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] in 2017 on the analysis of offshore financial centres "Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers: Conduits and Sinks in the Global Corporate Ownership Network"{{cite journal |author1=Javier Garcia-Bernardo|author2=Jan Fichtner|author3=Frank W. Takes|author4=Eelke M. Heemskerk | url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-06322-9 | volume=7 | issue=6246 | title=Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers: Conduits and Sinks in the Global Corporate Ownership Network | journal=[[Scientific Reports]], [[Nature Publishing Group]] | date=24 July 2017}} explains the disconnect between these two sets of contrasting views, and provides a more scientific approach to classification.{{cite web|url=https://corpnet.uva.nl/ofc/| title=Offshore Financial Centers and the Five Largest Value Conduits in the World|publisher=CORPNET|date=24 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ofcmeter.org/| title=What is an OFC Conduit and Sinks| publisher=CORPNET|date=2017}} The report was the result of a multi–year investigation by political economists and computer scientists in the CORPNET research group at the University of Amsterdam. CORPNET is a European Research Council funded group at the University of Amsterdam investigating networks of corporate control.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifcreview.com/restricted.aspx?articleId=12682|title=Sinks and Conduits: Identifying Offshore Financial Centres by using Big Data|publisher=IFC Review|date=1 March 2018}} The report used the Moody's [[Bureau van Dijk|Orbis corporate database]]{{cite web|url=https://www.bvdinfo.com/en-us/blog/transfer-pricing/-uncovering-offshore-financial-centers-conduits-a| title='Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers: Conduits and Sinks in the Global Corporate Ownership Network' - and how Orbis helped|publisher=Moodys BUREAU VAN DIJK|date=27 August 2017}} to examine 98 million global companies and their 71 million ownership connections (using [[big data]] computer modelling) to identify 5 global Conduit OFCs (Netherlands, United Kingdom, Ireland, Singapore and Switzerland). These are countries of high financial reputation (i.e. not formally labelled "tax havens" by OECD/EU), but who have "advanced" legal and tax structuring vehicles (and SPVs) that help legally route funds to the 24 tax havens (called Sink OFCs), without incurring tax in the Conduit OFC (or even tax in the source of funds location, where [[royalty payment]] schemes can be used).{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2017/07/25/new-research-key-role-major-economies-play-global-tax-avoidance/| title=New research on key role major economies play in global tax avoidance|publisher=Tax Justice Network|date=25 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/these-five-countries-are-conduits-for-the-worlds-biggest-tax-havens-79555| title=These five countries are conduits for the world’s biggest tax havens|publisher=theconversation.com|date=24 July 2017}} The work builds on methods established in the "Offshore–Intensity Ratio", and in particular the understanding activity relative to the scale of the domestic economy in a country.{{cite web|url=https://corpnet.uva.nl/apple-multinationals-avoid-taxes-accountability-network-study-offshore-finance/| title=How Apple and Other Multinationals Avoid Taxes and Accountability: A Network Study of Offshore Finance|publisher=CORPNET|date=27 September 2016}} At its crudest level, the Offshore-Intensity Ratio explains why the countries at the top of global [[List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita|GDP per capita]] lists are mostly [[tax haven]] types. The EU Parliament's Policy Department on Economic and Scientific Policies included the research in its findings for the EU Committee on Money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion (PANA),{{cite web|url=http://www.eppgroup.eu/PANA| title=PANA Committee on Money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion|publisher=EU Parliament|date=2018}} and by tabulating against existing EU–IMF–FSI tax–haven lists, showed material gaps in EU understanding of conduits.{{cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/cmsdata/115250/PANA%202016-04%20ST%20Offshore%20activities%20Final.pdf| title=Offshore activities and money laundering: recent findings and challenges|page=39|publisher=EU Parliament|date=March 2017}} CORPNET's top 5 Conduits and top 5 Sinks are 9 of the 10 largest tax havens identified in 2010 by one of the academic founders of tax haven research, [[James R. Hines Jr.]]. Hines' 2010 list of [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines 2010 list|10 major tax havens]] only differs in its omission of the U.K., which in 2010, had only just reformed its corporate tax system. CORPNET's top 5 Conduits and top 5 Sinks closely reconcile with the [[Corporate haven#Corporate tax haven lists|top 10 major corporate tax havens]] of other major academic and non–governmental organisation tax haven lists. ==Conduit OFC== {{see also|Corporate haven#GDP-per-capita tax haven proxy}} Conduit OFCs are described as having advanced legal and tax systems designed to enable corporations to route funds from high tax locations (e.g. Germany) to the Sink OFCs (e.g. Bermuda). They tend to have attractive "holding company" regimes (e.g. no withholding taxes, foreign dividends exempt from taxes, capital gains reliefs, full double–tax relief), advanced tax treatment of intellectual property regimes, and large global networks of bilateral [[tax treaties]].{{cite web | url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/these-five-countries-are-conduits-for-the-worlds-biggest_us_5975f0aee4b0f1feb89b4500| title=These Five Countries Are Conduits For The World’s Biggest Tax Havens|publisher=Huffington Post| date=24 July 2017}}{{cite web | url=https://www.ft.com/content/b83e697a-c625-11e7-b2bb-322b2cb39656| title=Stranger than paradise: the truth about tax|publisher=Financial Times| date=10 November 2017}} CORPNET's five major Conduit OFCs, all have a top–ten ranking in the 2018 ''[[Global Intellectual Property Center|Global Innovation Property Centre]] (GIPC) IP Index''.{{cite web|url=http://www.theglobalipcenter.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GIPC_IP_Index_2018.pdf|title=GIPC IP Index 2018|date=February 2018|author=[[United States Chamber of Commerce]]|quote=Figure I: U.S. Chamber International IP Index 2018, Overall Scores|page=6}} IP has been described as the "raw materials of corporate tax avoidance",{{cite web | url=https://www.bnrbeurs.nl/2017/02/22/the-corporate-tax-avoidance-toolbox/| title=The Corporate Tax Avoidance Toolbox|publisher=B&R Beurs|date=2018}} and "the leading corporate tax avoidance vehicle".{{cite web | url=https://www.uclalawreview.org/pdf/62-1-1.pdf | title=Intellectual Property Law Solutions to Tax Avoidance | author=Andrew Blair-Stanek|quote=Intellectual property (IP) has become the leading tax-avoidance vehicle.| publisher=UCLA Law Review |year=2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.fordhamiplj.org/2016/08/30/ip-tax-avoidance-ireland/ | title=Intellectual Property and Tax Avoidance in Ireland | publisher=[[Fordham Intellectual Property, Media & Entertainment Law Journal]] | date=30 August 2016}} Conduit OFCs tend to be dominated by major law firms and global accounting firms, who create the lawfully constructed vehicles that make the Sink OFC connections, by exploiting legislative [[loopholes]] such as the [[double Irish]] and [[dutch sandwich]]. They advise clients (and the Government) on anticipating future changes (e.g. from OECD BEPS processes), that may need new loopholes.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/06/world/apple-taxes-jersey.html|title=After a Tax Crackdown, Apple Found a New Shelter for Its Profits|publisher=New York Times|date=6 November 2017}} They write most of the State's relevant SPV legislation (where they create the new loopholes) through detailed lobbying and representations.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/matheson-lobbied-oecd-to-dilute-proposed-tax-rules-1.2601058?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fnews%2Fworld%2Feurope%2Fmatheson-lobbied-oecd-to-dilute-proposed-tax-rules-1.2601058| title=Law firm Matheson lobbied OECD to dilute proposed tax rules|publisher=Irish Times | date=7 April 2016}}{{cite web | url=https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/ie/Documents/Tax/ie-Tax-Coffey-Review-Public-Consultation-Paper.pdf| title=Consultation Paper on Review of Ireland’s Corporation Tax Code|publisher=Deloitte| date=January 2018}}{{cite web | url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-needs-to-stay-ahead-of-the-corporate-tax-reform-game-1.3218774?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Fireland-needs-to-stay-ahead-of-the-corporate-tax-reform-game-1.3218774| title=Ireland needs to stay ahead of the corporate tax reform game|publisher=Irish Times| date=13 September 2017}}{{cite web | url=https://www.somo.nl/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/tax-games-the-race-to-the-bottom.pdf| title=Tax Games|publisher=EURODAD|date=8 November 2017}} This type of legal and tax structuring is considered beyond the trust–structuring type work of the [[offshore magic circle]] firms. Conduit OFCs need structures that can integrate with bilateral tax treaties involving G20 countries, as well as meeting U.S. GAAP / SEC Regulations that U.S. multinationals (one of the largest users of Conduit OFCs) need to adhere to. These top 5 global Conduit OFCs channel 47% of corporate offshore connections and have different attributes:{{cite web | url=http://www.uva.nl/en/content/news/press-releases/2017/07/highly-developed-countries-canalise-almost-50-of-equity-flows-to-tax-havens.html| title=Highly developed countries canalise almost 50% of equity flows to tax havens|publisher=CORPNET| date=24 July 2017}} {{ordered list|type=lower-roman | {{flagcountry|NLD|1912}} – the largest{{cite web | url=https://www.complianceweek.com/blogs/global-glimpses/netherlands-not-bermuda-is-the-tax-evasion-capital-of-the-world| title=Netherlands, not Bermuda, is the tax evasion capital of the world|publisher=Compliance Week| date=30 July 2017}} Conduit OFC, and focused on routing funds from the EU (via "[[dutch sandwich]]") to the Sink OFC of Luxembourg and Sink OFC "triad" of Bermuda/BVI/Cayman.{{cite web | url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2017/07/the-netherlands-is-worlds-biggest-conduit-to-offshore-tax-havens-research/ | title=The Netherlands is world’s biggest conduit to offshore tax havens: research|publisher=Dutch News NL| date=24 July 2017}} | {{flagcountry|United Kingdom|1912}} – 2nd largest Conduit OFC, and the link from Europe to Asia; 18 of the 24 Sink OFCs are current, or past, dependencies of the U.K. (see table).{{cite web | url=https://www.accountancydaily.co/uk-second-largest-conduit-tax-havens| title=UK second largest conduit for tax havens|publisher=Accountancy Weekly| date=27 July 2017}}{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-eu-chancellor-philip-hammond-welt-am-sonntag-uk-tax-haven-europe-a7527961.html| title=UK could become 'tax haven' of Europe if it is shut out of single market after Brexit, Chancellor suggests|publisher=Independent| date=15 January 2017}} | {{flagcountry|CHE|1912}} – a major Conduit OFC for Jersey, the 4th largest Sink OFC. | {{flagcountry|SGP|1912}} – the main Conduit OFC for Asia, and the two major Asian Sink OFC Hong Kong and Sink OFC Taiwan. | {{flagcountry|IRE|1912}} – associated with US links (see [[Ireland as a tax haven]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.financialsecrecyindex.com/PDF/Ireland.pdf|title=Financial Secrecy Index 2018:IRELAND|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=February 2018}} who make heavy use of Sink OFC Luxembourg as a backdoor out of the Irish corporate tax system.{{cite web | url=https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/CR/Issues/2018/06/28/Ireland-Selected-Issues-46027|page=20|quote=Figure 3. Foreign Direct Investment - Over half of Irish outbound FDI is routed to Luxembourg|title=Ireland:Selected Issues|publisher=[[International Monetary Fund]]|date=June 2018}} }} ==Sink OFC== [[File:List of sink-OFCs, ordered by sink centrality value.png|thumb|"Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers": List of Sink OFCs ordered by value (showing U.K. dependencies)]] Sink OFCs cover a broad range of locations from very small counties (e.g. the Marshall Islands), to major global [[financial centres]] (e.g. Hong Kong). Just because funds reach a Sink OFC, does not mean that they remain dormant. Quite the contrary, the funds can be invested in assets all over the world, but their legal ownership and future gains remain in the Sink OFC. For example, the circa $1 trillion of US company offshore cash, is held in Sink OFCs (esp. Caribbean).{{cite web|url=https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-real-story-behind-us-companies-off-shore-cash-reserves| title=The real story behind US companies' offshore cash reserves | publisher=McKinsey & Company|date=June 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/20/us-corporate-giants-hoarding-over-a-trillion-dollars-apple-microsoft-google| title=US corporate giants hoarding more than a trillion dollars | work=The Guardian | date=20 May 2016}} The report highlighted some interesting aspects of the 24 Sink OFCs: {{ordered list|type=lower-roman | British Virgin Islands – in terms of connections, is the "Netherlands of Sink OFCs" and heavily linked with the Conduit OFC United Kingdom. | Luxembourg and Hong Kong – would have been considered Conduit OFCs, but the research shows they are even bigger Sink OFCs (i.e. longer–term homes for funds), Luxembourg (for routing funds from high–tax EU countries) and Hong Kong (for routing funds out of China) | Jersey – remains a unique link with major Conduit OFC, Switzerland (because the study could not capture individual "trusts", Jersey could be understated). | Bermuda, British Virgin Islands, Cayman Triad – these three classic offshore tax havens are heavily interlinked and starting to present as one large Sink OFC. | Taiwan – has been a controversial entrant on several tax haven lists (the [[Tax Justice Network]] calls Taiwan the "Switzerland of Asia",{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2016/02/10/taiwan-the-un-noticed-asian-tax-haven/|title=Taiwan, the un–noticed Asian tax haven?|publisher=Tax Justice Network|date=10 February 2016}} however, Taiwan is not on any EU/OECD/IMF tax-haven list), and is identified as the 2nd largest Asian Sink OFC. | Cayman Islands – the Cayman Islands are becoming the biggest financial centre for the Central and Latin America.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/latamcaribbean/2017/11/02/the-cayman-conundrum-why-is-one-tiny-archipelago-the-largest-financial-centre-in-latin-america-and-the-caribbean/|title=The Cayman conundrum: why is one tiny archipelago the largest financial centre in Latin America and the Caribbean?|publisher=London School of Economics|date=November 2017}} | Malta – the report highlights the rise of Sink OFC Malta as an emerging tax haven "inside" the EU,{{cite web|url=https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/79320/scientists_find_name_for_maltas_tax_haven_rep_#.WsIY14jwZPY|title=Scientists have found a way of showing how Malta is a global top ten tax haven|publisher=Malta Today|date=31 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20170729/local/malta-is-main-eu-tax-haven-study.654369|title=Malta is a Tax Haven, major new study|publisher=Times Malta|date=29 July 2017}} which has been a source of wider media scrutiny.{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20170520/local/malta-is-a-target-for-italian-mafia-russia-loan-sharks-damning-report.648474|title=Malta is a target for Italian mafia, Russia loan sharks, damning probe says|publisher=Times of Malta|date=20 May 2017}} | Mauritius – has become a major Sink OFC for both SE Asia (especially India) and African economies, and now ranking 8th overall.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/nov/03/deloittes-tax-savings-investments-in-poor-countries|title=Deloitte promotes Mauritius as tax haven to avoid big payouts to poor African nations|publisher=The Guardian|date=3 November 2013}} }} ==OECD failings on tax havens== {{quote box |width=19em|border=1px|align=right|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|qalign=left |quote = Of the wider tax environment, O’Rourke thinks the OECD base–erosion and profit–shifting (BEPS) process is “very good” for Ireland. “If BEPS sees itself to a conclusion, it will be good for Ireland.” |salign=left |source=[[Feargal O'Rourke]] CEO PwC (Ireland)
"Architect" of the [[double Irish]]{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-10-28/man-making-ireland-tax-avoidance-hub-globally-proves-local-hero| title=Man Making Ireland Tax Avoidance Hub Proves Local Hero | publisher=Bloomberg News|date=28 October 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/controversial-tax-strategies-brainchild-of-orourkes-son-29721835.html| title=Controversial tax strategies brainchild of O'Rourke's son| publisher=Irish Independent|date=3 November 2013}}
Irish Times, 2015{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/scion-of-a-prominent-political-dynasty-who-gave-his-vote-to-accountancy-1.2203820?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ffinancial-services%2Fscion-of-a-prominent-political-dynasty-who-gave-his-vote-to-accountancy-1.2203820| title=Scion of a prominent political dynasty who gave his vote to accountancy| publisher=Irish Times|date=8 May 2015}} }} CORPNET highlighted the lack of progress the OECD [[Base erosion and profit shifting]] ("BEPS") project is making, and that the OECD's support of transparent [[intellectual property]]–based tax structuring (or patent/knowledge boxes), is incompatible with the emerging position of intellectual property as the leading [[BEPS]] tool in conduit OFCs.{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2017/09/11/new-un-tax-handbook-sets-lower-income-countries-oecd-beps/|title=New UN tax handbook: Lower–income countries vs OECD BEPS failure|publisher=Tax Justice Network| date=11 September 2017}} The reasons for this failure are discussed in [[Corporate haven#Failure of OECD BEPS Project|failure of OECD BEPS Project]]. An example of an IP–based [[Base erosion and profit shifting|BEPS tool]] is Ireland's [[double Irish arrangement#Backstop of capital allowances|capital allowances for intangible assets]] ("CAIA") tool, also known as the "[[Ireland as a tax haven#Green Jersey|Green Jersey]]", which has an [[Corporation tax in the Republic of Ireland#Effective tax rate (ETR)|effective tax rate]] of 0–3%. Apple used the CAIA (or Green Jersey) BEPS tool in Q1 2015 (and created the noted Irish "[[leprechaun economics]]" restatement of GDP). Ireland has other IP–based [[Base erosion and profit shifting|BEPS tools]] (Ireland as the first OECD nexus-compliant [[Corporation tax in the Republic of Ireland#Knowledge development box|KDB]]),{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/oecd-gives-cautious-welcome-to-knowledge-box-tax-scheme-30685281.html|title=OECD gives cautious welcome to Irish Knowledge Box tax scheme|publisher=Irish Independent|date=23 October 2014}} and is a supporter of the [[Base erosion and profit shifting (OECD project)|OECD BEPS project]] (see box). ==Isle of Man omitted== The Isle of Man (the "IOM") was absent from the list of top Sink OFCs. The IOM appears on tax–haven lists and ranks 42 on the 2018 [[Financial Secrecy Index]].{{cite web|url=https://www.financialsecrecyindex.com/introduction/fsi-2018-results| title=Financial Secrecy Index 2018| publisher=Tax Justice Network| date=2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.financialsecrecyindex.com/PDF/IsleofMan.pdf| title=Report on the Isle of Man| publisher=Tax Justice Network| date=2017}} The Chief Minister of the IOM, [[Howard Quayle]], announced that the CORPNET report proved that the IOM is not a tax haven.{{cite web|url=http://www.iomtoday.co.im/article.cfm?id=35167&headline=We%27re%20no%20tax%20haven%20study%20concludes§ionIs=news&searchyear=2017| title=We're no tax haven study concludes | publisher=IOM Today | date=1 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://business-reporter.co.uk/2017/11/07/isle-man-closely-mirrors-uk-rules-says-chief-minister/?getcat=2934| title=Isle of man ‘closely mirrors’ UK rules, says Chief Minister| publisher=Daily Telegraph Business Reporter | date=7 November 2017}} However, CORPNET researchers from the University of Amsterdam directly replied to Howard Quayle's article{{cite web|url=https://corpnet.uva.nl/response-to-howard-quayle-chief-minister-of-isle-of-man/| title=Response to Howard Quayle, Chief Minister of Isle of Man| publisher=CORPNET| date=8 November 2017}} clarifying that while the IOM does not appear as a leading Sink OFC for corporate tax avoidance, it does not mean that individuals (personal bank accounts and trusts) do not use the IOM to avoid taxes, and particularly United Kingdom VAT. Other commentators have added that the IOM is "failing as a tax haven", and is now too small to appear in major studies like the CORPNET research.{{cite web|url=http://www.taxresearch.org.uk/Blog/2017/08/02/the-isle-of-man-is-failing-at-being-a-tax-haven/| title=The Isle of Man is failing at being a tax haven| publisher=Tax Research UK| date=2 August 2017}} == Ireland underestimated == {{see also|Corporate tax haven|Ireland as a tax haven}} The CORPNET report uses corporate connections on the [[Bureau van Dijk|Orbis database]], rather than the quantum of money, as its primary metric of analysis. In theory, the authors feel that this does not impede the goal of classification, and of making relative rankings. However, it does mean the amount of potential tax avoidance is ignored. Acclaimed author on tax havens and offshore financial centers, [[Gabriel Zucman]], uses a different quantitative approach. Zucman focuses on macro–data of national statistical accounts. In theory, the total assets in a system should equal the total liabilities. By aggregating national account data, Zucman can identify an excess of liabilities over assets, implying that the missing assets (to balance the equation), are hidden in tax–havens. On this basis, in 2015, he estimated that 8% of the world's wealth (or $7.6 trillion) was "missing" in offshore tax–havens.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/16/opinion/a-piketty-proteges-theory-on-tax-havens.html|title=The True Cost of Hidden Money|publisher=New York Times |date=15 June 2014}} Zucman's analysis highlights the special case of Ireland and why the Orbis database underestimates Ireland's scale as one of the world's largest corporate tax avoidance, or [[base erosion and profit shifting|BEPS]], hubs.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/nov/08/tax-havens-dodging-theft-multinationals-avoiding-tax|title=The desperate inequality behind global tax dodging|publisher=The Guardian| date=8 November 2017}} US multinationals dominate Ireland's economy, using it as a shield from the US "worldwide tax" system (pre 2017 [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017|TCJA]] leglislation).{{Cite web|title = A Territorial Tax System Would Create Jobs and Raise Wages for U.S. Workers|url = https://www.heritage.org/taxes/report/territorial-tax-system-would-create-jobs-and-raise-wages-us-workers|publisher = The Heritage Foundation|date = 12 September 2013}} They are 14 of Ireland's 20 largest firms,{{cite web|url=http://www.top1000.ie/companies| title=Ireland's Top 1000 Companies | publisher=Irish Times| date=2018}} directly employ one–quarter of the labour force,{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/investment/IRELAND-trade-investment-statistical-country-note.pdf|title=IRELAND Trade and Statistical Note 2017|publisher=OECD|date=2017}} pay 80% of all business taxes,{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/corporate/documents/research/corporation-tax-returns-2016.pdf|title=An Analysis of 2015 Corporation Tax Returns and 2016 Payments|publisher=Revenue Commissioners|date=April 2017}} and create 57% of non–farm private sector OECD value–add. There are no non–US/non–UK foreign firms in Ireland's top 50 firms by turnover (and only one by employees, Lidl). When Apple restructured its Irish subsidiaries in January 2015, it caused Irish GDP to rise 26.3% and Irish GNP to rise 18.7% (became the [[leprechaun economics]] affair). Zucman's analysis shows many of Ireland's US multinationals don't appear on Orbis (Facebook), or only have a small fraction of their data on Orbis (Google and Apple). Analysed using "quantum of funds" (not "Orbis connections"), Zucman shows Ireland is one of the largest corporate tax shelters in the world, and a route for Zucman’s estimated loss of 20% in EU corporate tax revenues annually.{{cite web|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/TWZ2018Slides.pdf|page=35|title=The Missing Profits of Nations|author=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers| date=April 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporations-push-profits-into-tax-havens-as-countries-struggle-in-pursuit-study-says-1528634659|title=Zucman:Corporations Push Profits Into Corporate Tax Havens as Countries Struggle in Pursuit, Gabrial Zucman Study Says|quote=The new research draws on data from countries such as Ireland, Luxembourg and the Netherlands that hadn’t previously been collected.|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=10 June 2018}} ==See also== * [[Corporate tax haven]] * [[Tax haven]] * [[Offshore Financial Centres]] * [[Financial Centres]] * [[James R. Hines Jr.]] * [[Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy]] * [[Financial Secrecy Index]] * [[Base erosion and profit shifting]] * [[Offshore magic circle]] * [[Ireland as a tax haven]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://corpnet.uva.nl/ University of Amsterdam CORPNET] * [http://www.jfichtner.net/visualizations-of-global-finance/ Jan Fichtner Offshore–Intensity Ratio] * [http://gabriel-zucman.eu/ Gabrial Zucman, University College Berkley] * [https://www.bvdinfo.com/en-gb/our-products/data/international/orbis Moody's ORBIS Database] * [https://www.taxjustice.net/ Tax Justice Network] * [https://www.oxfam.org/en/tags/corporate-tax-avoidance Oxfam Corporate Tax Avoidance Portal] * [https://itep.org/ Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy] [[Category:International taxation]] [[Category:Economic globalization]] [[Category:International finance]] [[Category:Offshore finance]] [[Category:Tax avoidance]] [[Category:Corporate tax avoidance]]

A '''credit analyst''' is a person employed by an organization to analyze the credit worthiness of customers and potential customers. Job responsibilities may include: * Reviewing credit applications * Projecting sales * Evaluating credit risk * Analyzing financial data, statements and trends * Setting new customer credit limits * Recommending credit limits based on company credit policies * Performing credit reviews of existing customers * Maintaining customer files with financial statements and bank reference information * Resolving credit issues * Monitoring risk trends on behalf of management and sales personnel<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nacmnc.org/networking/|title=Careers in Credit - NACM North Central|last=|first=|date=|website=nacmnc.org|publisher=|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref>
== Education == Credit analysts often hold a bachelor's degree in finance, accounting, business administration or economics. Some companies may require a Credit Business Associate certification from the [[National Association of Credit Management]](NACM).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://learn.org/articles/How_Do_I_Become_a_Credit_Analyst.html|title=How Do I Become a Credit Analyst?|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref>
== Employment == In May 2015, the [[Bureau of Labor Statistics|U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics]] reported 70,840 people employed as credit analysts. The salary for this position ranged from $40,250 to $134,080 with a mean average wage of $79,720.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes132041.htm|title=Credit Analysts|website=www.bls.gov|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref>
== Professional Organizations == Credit analysts in the United States can obtain memberships, continuing education and certification through NACM. Certification levels include Credit Business Associate, Certified Credit and Risk Analyst, Credit Business Fellow, Certified Credit Executive, Certified International Credit Professional and International Certified Credit Executive.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nacm.org/certification.html|title=The National Association of Credit Management: Certification Programs|last=NACM|website=nacm.org|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref>

'''Cristian David''' (born '''Cristian Troacă'''; December 26, 1967) is a [[Romania]]n politician. A member of the [[National Liberal Party (Romania)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL), he has been a member of the [[Senate of Romania|Romanian Senate]] for [[Vaslui County]] since 2004. In the [[Călin Popescu-Tăriceanu]] cabinet, he was Minister-Delegate for International Financing Programs and European Community Acquis from 2004 to 2007 and [[Ministry of Administration and Interior (Romania)|Minister of Interior and Administrative Reform]] from 2007 to 2008.
==Biography==
He was born in [[Bucharest]], and worked at a chemical equipment factory there from 1986 to 1991, rising to design engineer in 1990. Between 1992 and 2004, he held management positions at three different firms involved in import/export and consulting.<ref name="cvsenator"/> He paused his business activity from 1997 to 1998, when he was an adviser to the [[Ministry of Youth and Sport (Romania)|Youth and Sport Minister]], the future PNL President [[Crin Antonescu]].<ref name="cvsenator"/><ref name="vlasov">{{ro icon}} Mirela Corlăţan, Lucian Gheorghiu, [http://old.cotidianul.ro/guvernul_patriciu_fenechiu-24193.html "Guvernul Patriciu-Fenechiu" ("The Patriciu-Fenechiu Government")] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827045809/http://old.cotidianul.ro/guvernul_patriciu_fenechiu-24193.html |date=2010-08-27 }}, ''Evenimentul Zilei'', 2 April 2007; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> In 1997 he graduated from the Faculty of Statistics, Cybernetics, and Computer Science of the [[Bucharest Academy of Economic Studies]], earning a doctorate in economics there in 2006. He was assistant professor in the Statistics and Economic Forecasting Department there from 2001 to 2004.<ref name="cvsenator">{{ro icon}} [https://www.senat.ro/FisaSenator.aspx?ParlamentarID=7cbd4c69-f2bb-4351-8567-418cc523bef0 Profile] at the Romanian Senate site; accessed August 25, 2010</ref>
Entering politics after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|fall]] of the [[Communist Romania|Communist regime]], he was coordinator of the University [[National Liberal Youth (Romania)|National Liberal Youth]] (TNL) from 1990 to 1993, rising to secretary general from 1993 to 1997. He belonged to the PNL's permanent central bureau in 1991-1993 and 2005-2006, and headed its foreign affairs department from 1997 to 2005. He was on the delegation of PNL national representatives in 2002-2004, and from 2003 to 2004 was on the electoral committee of the [[European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party]], in advance of the [[European Parliament election, 2004 (Romania)|2004 European Parliament election]].<ref name="cvsenator"/> During his first term in the Senate (2004-2008), he sat on the human rights, religious affairs and national minorities committee.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.cdep.ro/pls/parlam/structura.mp?idm=27&cam=1&leg=2004&pag=1&idl=1 2004-2008 parliamentary profile]; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> In his second term (2008-), he is on the joint committee providing oversight to the activities of ''[[Serviciul Român de Informaţii]]''.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.cdep.ro/pls/parlam/structura.mp?idm=39&cam=1&leg=2008&pag=1&idl=1 2008-2012 parliamentary profile]; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> Additionally, David held two positions in the Tăriceanu cabinet: Minister-Delegate for International Financing Programs and European Community Acquis from December 2004 to April 2007, when the post was disbanded, and Interior Minister from then until the cabinet left office in December 2008.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documentare.rompres.ro/guverne.php?i=12 Călin Popescu-Tăriceanu Government]; accessed August 25, 2010</ref>
David's first marriage took place in 2001, at which time he adopted his wife's surname, and ended in divorce.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.ziaruldeiasi.ro/national-extern/cristian-david-lsd-cocaina-si-amfetamina~ni52sg "Cristian David, LSD, cocaină şi amfetamină" ("Cristian David, LSD, Cocaine and Amphetamines")], ''Ziarul de Iaşi'', 18 November 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref><ref name="revista2">{{ro icon}} [http://www.revista22.ro/abraham-ministrul-cristian-david-avea-droguri-in-casa-5019.html "Abraham: Ministrul Cristian David avea droguri în casă" ("Abraham: Minister Cristian David Had Drugs in His House")], ''22'', 18 November 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> His second marriage took place quietly in November 2005 in [[Vienna]], with a [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian Orthodox]] ceremony following six months later.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.observatordebacau.ro/2008/08/01/cancan-cristian-david-si-vanda-vlasov-divort-rapid.html "Cancan: Cristian David şi Vanda Vlasov, divorţ rapid" ("Cancan: Cristian David and Vanda Vlasov, Quick Divorce")], ''Observator de Bacău'', 1 August 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref><ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.9am.ro/stiri-revista-presei/Politica/33984/Ministrii-liberali-au-dansat-pe-rupte-la-cununia-colegului-Cristian-David.html "Miniştrii liberali au dansat pe rupte la cununia colegului Cristian David" ("Liberal Ministers Dance Lustily at Colleague Cristian David's Wedding")], ''Click'', 22 May 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> His second wife is Vanda Vlasov, daughter of the [[Iaşi]] lawyer [[Mihail Vlasov]]. Already an ally of the businessman and politician [[Relu Fenechiu]], David consolidated his relationship with Fenechiu through the marriage due to the latter's connections with Mihail Vlasov. Later, while Minister-Delegate, David was accused of taking no action when allegations surfaced that Vlasov embezzled [[Euro|€]]211,000 in [[European Union]] funds.<ref name="vlasov"/> Two scandals hit David near the end of his ministerial service. In October 2008, it emerged that the [[Romanian Police]], a part of his ministry, had signed contracts to purchase [[Dacia Logan]]s for some €70,000 each, with the opposition PD-L calling for his resignation and asserting that the police bought the cars for €12,000 under his PD-L predecessor.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://old.cotidianul.ro/pd_l_cere_demisia_lui_cristian_david_pentru_minciuna_si_fuga_de_raspundere-61130.html "PD-L cere demisia lui Cristian David pentru 'minciună şi fugă de răspundere'" ("PD-L Calls on Cristian David to Resign for 'Lies and Fleeing Responsibility'")] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726051946/http://old.cotidianul.ro/pd_l_cere_demisia_lui_cristian_david_pentru_minciuna_si_fuga_de_raspundere-61130.html |date=2011-07-26 }}, ''Cotidianul'', 15 October 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> David refused to resign, instead firing police chief [[Gheorghe Popa]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Raluca Dan, [http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/david-ministrul-da-vina-si-fugi-824790.html "David, ministrul 'Dă vina şi fugi!'" ("David, Minister of 'Blame and Flee!'")], ''Evenimentul Zilei'', 17 October 2008; accessed August 25, 2010</ref> The following month, [[Pavel Abraham]], a former chief of the Romanian Police, alleged that in 1995, police officers searching David's home discovered [[Lysergic acid diethylamide|LSD]], [[amphetamine]] and [[cocaine]]. In reply, David stated that the residence was his girlfriend's and was being rented to his [[Netherlands|Dutch]] business partner, and that he was questioned as a witness in the case.<ref name="revista2"/>

{{Infobox person |name = Fahd Ananta |image = Fahd Ananta.jpg |image_size = |caption = Fahd Ananta in 2013 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1988|12|22|mf=yes}} |birth_place = [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] |residence = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada |nationality = |ethnicity = |alma_mater = [[University of Waterloo]] (attended) [[University of Toronto]] (attended) |occupation = |known_for = [[internet entrepreneur]], co-founder of Chime and Tab Payments |salary = |networth = |spouse = |children = |website = |footnotes = |signature = |signature_alt = }}
'''Fahd Ananta''' (born 1988, [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]]) is an internet entrepreneur and co-founder of [[Google Chrome]] extension '''Chime'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/person/fahd-ananta |title=Fahd Ananta - Co-founder of Chime|publisher=Crunchbase |date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref> as well as mobile payments company '''Tab Payments'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techvibes.com/blog/tab-mobile-payments-solution-uber-2014-04-23 |title=Canadian Startup Tab Launches Elegant Mobile Payments Solution |publisher=TechVibes |date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref>
==Early life==
He was born on the December 22, 1988 in [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]]. He is the eldest child and has a younger sister.
==Career==
Fahd attended the [[University of Waterloo]] for a Bachelor of Mathematics from which he dropped out to work at [[BlackBerry]]. Thereafter, he spent a two-year span working for the [[Toronto Transit Commission]] and building genome analysis software for the [[Ontario Institute for Cancer Research]]. In 2010, he attended the [[University of Toronto]] to study Computer Science and Neuroscience. While in school, he began working at [[McDonald's]] to observe behaviors of people.
As a student, he joined [[Microsoft]] ([[MSN]], [[Outlook.com]]) and met friends '''Thariq Shihipar''' and '''Guru Mahendran''' with whom he co-founded '''Chime'''. After Chime was acquired<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.utoronto.ca/u-t-undergraduate-entrepreneurs-sell-web-services-startup |title=U of T undergraduate entrepreneurs sell web services startup|publisher=University of Toronto|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref> by [[HubSpot]], Ananta went to help [[McKinsey]] build a product studio. In August 2013, he moved back to [[Toronto]] to join friends in founding '''Tab'''.
=== Chime ===
Ananta founded '''Chime''' in 2011 with friends Thariq Shihipar and Guru Mahendran. Chime is a [[Google Chrome]] browser extension. Users are able to view and interact with their notifications and messages from popular websites and applications such as [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], [[Gmail]], and many others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chimeapp.com/ |title=Chime|publisher=Chime|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref> Chime launched to the public in January 2012 and garnered a significantly positive response from the online community.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thenextweb.com/apps/2013/01/31/chime-for-chrome-aggregates-all-your-notifications-from-gmail-twitter-facebook-and-more/ |title=Chime for Chrome aggregates all your notifications from Gmail, Twitter, Facebook and more|publisher=The Next Web|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geekwire.com/2013/chrome-addon-puts-gmail-social-media-notifications-place/ |title=This Chrome add-on puts your Gmail, social media notifications all in one place|publisher=GeekWire|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lifehacker.com/5980731/chime-collects-and-organizes-notifications-from-all-your-popular-web-services-under-one-button |title=Chime Collects and Organizes Notifications from All Your Popular Web Services Under One Button|publisher=Lifehacker|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.addictivetips.com/web/chime-chrome-notifications-for-gmail-facebook-twitter-reddit-foursquare-more/ |title=Get Notifications For Gmail, Facebook, Twitter & More In Chrome With Chime|publisher=AddictiveTips|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref> It was acquired by marketing automation company [[HubSpot]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/03/28/hubspot-acquires-chime-prepwork/ |title=HubSpot Acquires Notification Aggregator Chime And Calendar App PrepWork|publisher=TechCrunch|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-acquires-chime-and-prepwork |title=Why We Acquired Two More Companies ... And We're Just Getting Started|publisher=HubSpot|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/03/28/hubspot-acquires-chime-and-prepwork-promising-more-come/XRyrqnph4dx0uRA0boPq2N/story.html |title=HubSpot acquires Chime and PrepWork, promising more to come|publisher=Boston Globe|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref> in February 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vator.tv/news/2013-03-28-hubspot-picks-up-startups-chime-and-prepwork |title=HubSpot picks up startups Chime and PrepWork |publisher=VatorTV|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref> and combined with what became '''Sidekick'''.
=== Tab ===
In November 2013, Ananta founded '''Tab''' (Tab Payments) in Toronto to help diners pay the bill through their phone in restaurants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blogto.com/tech/2014/06/get_to_know_a_toronto_startup_tab/ |title=Get to know a Toronto startup: Tab|publisher=BlogTO|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.utoronto.ca/pay-summerlicious-restaurant-meals-and-more-tap-finger-u-t-alumni-startup-tab |title=Pay for Summerlicious restaurant meals and more with the tap of a finger: U of T alumni startup, Tab|publisher=University of Toronto|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref> Tab is a mobile application used to close the bill at restaurants. Diners inform their server that they will be using Tab for their meal and simply leave when they are ready. Their payment information stored on file is billed and they are sent a receipt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mobilesyrup.com/2014/04/22/tab-for-iphone-takes-the-hailo-approach-to-dining-out-launches-in-toronto/ |title=Tab for iPhone takes the Hailo approach to dining out, launches in Toronto|publisher=MobileSyrup|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref> Upon launch, Tab was operational in 25 partner restaurants in Toronto.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/technology/tech-news/app-aims-to-make-dine-and-dash-acceptable/article20540316/ |title=App aims to make dine and dash acceptable|publisher=The Globe and Mail|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/app-lets-restaurant-patrons-dine-dash-bill-comes-193357494.html?pt=tAD2SCT8P7 |title=New app makes dining and dashing...legal|publisher=Yahoo Finance|date= |accessdate=2014-10-03}}</ref> In August 2014, Ananta announced to the company that he will step down from his role as Chief Technical Officer and Head of Product.

[[University of Michigan]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = |influences = |influenced = |awards = |religion = |signature = |footnotes = }} '''George Martin Zinkhan, III''' (February 17, 1952 – [[Circa|c.]] May 9, 2009){{cite web|last=Zinkhan |first=George |title=Curriculum Vitae |date=2004-04-26 |url=http://www.terry.uga.edu/~gzinkhan/data/vitae.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-04-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070203084648/http://www.terry.uga.edu/~gzinkhan/data/vitae.pdf |archivedate=February 3, 2007 }}{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/05/09/georgia.professor.shooting/index.html | work=CNN | title=Authorities: Body of UGA professor identified - CNN.com | accessdate=2010-05-03 | date=2009-05-11}} was an [[United States of America|American]] [[academia|academic]] and [[poetry|poet]]. Zinkhan was a professor of [[marketing]] at the [[University of Georgia]] from 1994 until April 26, 2009.{{cite news |last = |first = |coauthors = |title = UGA Professor Fired, Still on the Run |language = |publisher = 11 Alive |date = 2009-04-27 |url = http://www.11alive.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=129545&catid=3 |accessdate = 2009-04-27 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = FBI: Wanted professor bought plane ticket to Netherlands | language = | publisher = CNN | date = 2009-04-27 | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/04/27/georgia.shootings/?iref=mpstoryview | accessdate = 2009-04-27}} He was named as the prime suspect in a triple homicide before authorities announced on May 9, 2009 that they had found and identified Zinkhan's body. ==Career== In 1974, Zinkhan received his [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[English literature]] from [[Swarthmore College]]. This was followed by a [[Masters in Business Administration]] with high distinction from the [[University of Michigan]] in 1979. Zinkhan also received his doctorate in [[Business Administration]] from the [[University of Michigan]] in 1981. Zinkhan was the Conn Professor of Marketing for thirteen years at the [[University of Houston]] beginning in 1981. While there, he sexually harassed multiple female academics and ultimately had a lawsuit brought against him. For one year he also was an associate professor for the [[University of Pittsburgh]] in 1987. He began as a professor at the [[University of Georgia]]'s [[Terry College of Business]] in 1994, and served as Department head for Terry's Department of Marketing and Distribution from 1994 until 2001. He held an endowed chair as the department's [[Coca-Cola Company]] Professor from 1994 to 2009.{{cite web|title=Terry College of Business: Profile for George Zinkhan |work= |publisher=The [[University of Georgia]], Terry College of Business |date=2000–2008 |url=http://www.terry.uga.edu/profiles/?person_id=457 |accessdate=2009-04-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202135029/http://www.terry.uga.edu/profiles/?person_id=457 |archivedate=February 2, 2009 }} According to a university spokesman, he had an impeccable track record as a teacher and was a respected professor on campus.{{cite news | last = Weber | first = Harry R | title = 3 dead, 2 hurt in Ga. shooting; professor sought | work = Associated Press | date = 2009-04-25 | url = http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_GEORGIA_PROFESSOR_SHOOTING?SITE=AP&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090502010808/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_GEORGIA_PROFESSOR_SHOOTING?SITE=AP&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2009-05-02 | accessdate = 2009-04-25 | df = }} ==Awards== Zinkhan received an award for Outstanding Contribution to Research in 2004 which was presented by the [[American Academy of Advertising]]. He also received the ''Terry Outstanding Faculty Award'' 2006 and 2009 presented by the economics faculty of the Vrije Universiteit.[http://www.feweb-vu.nl/ebiss/itemware/news/15572/detail/george_zinkhan_wins_2009_terry_outstanding_faculty_award.html George Zinkhan wins 2009 Terry Outstanding Faculty Award]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Faculteit der Economische Wetenschappen en Bedrijfskunde Vrije Universiteit, 17 April 2009 ==Publications== Zinkhan published over 100 articles in [[peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]]s, as well as numerous chapters in edited books. He was the editor of the ''[[Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science]]'' from 2003 to 2006, and of the ''[[Journal of Advertising]]'' from 1991 to 1995, as well as the book review editor of the ''[[Journal of Marketing]]'' from 1991 to 1995. In addition, he edited or co-edited several books: *{{cite book | last = Arnould | first = Eric | authorlink = | author2 = Linda Price | author3 = George Zinkhan | title = Consumers | publisher = McGraw Hill / Irwin | year = 2004 | location = | pages = | url = | isbn = 0-07-253714-0}} *{{cite book | last = Watson | first = Richard | authorlink = | author2 = Pierre Berthon | author3 = Leyland F. Pitt | author4 = George Zinkhan | title = Electronic Commerce: The Strategic Perspective | publisher = Thompson / Dryden | year = 2000 | location = | page = 162 pages | url = | nopp = yes | isbn = 0-03-026533-9}} *{{cite book |author=Zinkhan, George M. |title=Advertising research: the Internet, consumer behavior, and strategy |publisher=American Marketing Association |location=Chicago, Ill |year=2000 |pages= |isbn=0-87757-288-7 |oclc= |accessdate=}} Zinkhan's ''[[curriculum vitae]]'' listed 22 works under a section called, "Research Activities: Poetry".{{cite web|url=http://www.accessnorthga.com/detail.php?n=219909 |title=GBI releases Zinkhan case file |publisher=AccessNorthGa |date=2009-12-06 |accessdate=2012-08-12}} Zinkhan's poems—many of which the [[American Marketing Association]] published on its website—cover topics ranging from university politics to the [[Appalachian Trail]].{{cite web|last=Boone |first=Christian |url=http://www.ajc.com/services/content/metro/stories/2009/04/28/ugasearch_zinkhan_Oconee.html |title=Atlanta Metro News |publisher=ajc.com |date=2009-04-28 |accessdate=2012-08-12}} ==Personal life== Zinkhan had two children, a son and a daughter, with his wife, attorney Marie Bruce.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} Zinkhan also had three children from a previous marriage.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} The family lived in the town of [[Bogart, Georgia|Bogart]] in the U.S. state of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].[http://media.www.redandblack.com/media/storage/paper871/news/2009/04/27/News/Zinkhan.odd.Prolific.Professor-3726732.shtml "Zinkhan 'odd,' prolific professor"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430101023/http://media.www.redandblack.com/media/storage/paper871/news/2009/04/27/News/Zinkhan.odd.Prolific.Professor-3726732.shtml |date=2009-04-30 }}, by Daniel Burdett, ''[[The Red and Black]]'' Zinkhan owned a second home in [[Amsterdam]], the capital of the [[Netherlands]], where he was a marketing professor at the [[Vrije Universiteit]]. ==Murder charges== Zinkhan was named the prime suspect in the April 25, 2009, shooting deaths of his wife and two other people, Tom Tanner and Ben Teague, outside the Athens Community Theatre in [[Athens, Georgia|Athens-Clarke County]] in northeast Georgia. The murders occurred during a picnic reunion of the Town & Gown Players, and all three of those killed were active in local theater productions. Two bystanders were injured by bullet fragments. According to neighbors and colleagues, there had been no advance signs of trouble.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Georgia professor sought in shooting death of wife, two others | language = | publisher =CNN | date = 2009-04-25 | url =http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/04/25/georgia.shootings/index.html | accessdate = 2009-04-25}} Police said Zinkhan and his wife, Marie Bruce, were having “marital difficulties,” that Tom Tanner appeared to be his “specific target” in the shootings and that Ben Teague was “at the wrong place at the wrong time.” Tanner was shot first, police said.[http://www.ajc.com/services/content/metro/stories/2009/05/12/zinkhan_grave.html Athens killer lay in grave under pallet, shot himself], [[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]], May 12, 2009 On the same day, "Zinkhan was charged with three counts of murder and a state [[arrest warrant]] was issued in Clarke County, Georgia. A federal arrest warrant was issued on April 26, 2009, after he was charged with unlawful flight to avoid prosecution." ==Death== Zinkhan's red [[Jeep Liberty]] was found on the night of April 30, 2009, in northwest [[Clarke County, Georgia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wrdw.com/home/headlines/44126872.html|title=Update: Zinkhan's vehicle located|first=Associated|last=Press|publisher=}} Cadaver dogs located Zinkhan's body on May 9, 2009, approximately one mile from the Jeep.{{cite web |url=http://www.wsbtv.com/news/19416286/detail.html |title=Police: Missing UGA Professor Found Dead |publisher=www.wsbtv.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629131700/http://www.wsbtv.com/news/19416286/detail.html |archivedate=2011-06-29 |df= }}[http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/stories/2009/05/09/body_found_near_zinkhan_car.html "Zinkhan’s body found in grave he dug"], by Rhonda Cook, Kent A. Miles, Chip Towers; "[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]", May 9, 2009 Investigators said that Zinkhan used a shovel to dig a {{convert|15|to|18|in|mm|adj=mid|-deep}} grave in the woods behind [[Clarke County School District|Cleveland Road Elementary]], lay down in it, took an old wooden pallet he had covered with dirt and debris and pulled it over top of the hole.[http://chronicle.augusta.com/stories/latest/lat_519041.shtml "Police say Zinkhan targeted Tanner, committed suicide"], by Allison Floyd; [[The Augusta Chronicle]]", May 12, 2009 He then fired a single shot from a .38-caliber handgun into his head. Zinkhan's body was claimed by a son from a previous marriage one day before it was scheduled for burial in a pauper's grave by the Athens-Clarke County coroner's office.[http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/05/15/zinkhan.body/index.html Son claims body of professor accused in killings], [[CNN]], May 16, 2009 ==References== {{Wikinews|Professor sought after three die in Georgia shooting}} {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zinkhan, George}} [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:Poets from Maryland]] [[Category:American print editors]] [[Category:Business educators]] [[Category:American marketing people]] [[Category:Writers from Baltimore]] [[Category:People from Clarke County, Georgia]] [[Category:Suicides by firearm in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Swarthmore College alumni]] [[Category:University of Georgia faculty]] [[Category:University of Houston faculty]] [[Category:University of Pittsburgh faculty]] [[Category:Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam faculty]] [[Category:Murder–suicides in the United States]] [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:Ross School of Business alumni]] [[Category:20th-century American poets]]

[[File:Giorgio Rossi Cairo Value Partners.jpg|thumb|Giorgio Rossi Cairo]] '''Giorgio Rossi Cairo''' ([[Varese]], 15 July 1947) is an Italian entrepreneur. He is managing director of [[Value Partners (management consulting)|Value Partners]], the management consulting multinational he founded in 1993.
== Biography == Degree in Aerospace Engineering from the [[Milan_Polytechnic|Polytechnic University of Milan]] and graduate of the Executive Program in Finance at INSEAD, [[Fontainebleau]].
From 1972 to 1973 he was a CNR researcher at the Polytechnic University of Milan. He subsequently worked until 1978 as Executive Vice President of the Transportation Planning Division at Polytecna Harris, an Italian-American engineering company.[1]
From 1979 to 1992, he was a director of [[McKinsey & Company]] and a member of the Principal Candidate Evaluation Committee.[2]
In 1993, he founded [http://www.valuepartners.com/en/ Value Partners], a global management consulting firm with 6 offices in 5 countries: Milan (headquarters), London, Rio de Janeiro, Buenos Aires, Shanghai and Hong Kong.
In 2000, he set up Value Team, a system integrator specializing in business-critical IT services. In April 2011, Value Team was sold to NTT DATA.
In 2016, he founded Exage, a company with focus on digital Innovation. Exage helps companies to navigate through the challenges of digital transformation and to manage issues such as cyber security, big data, digital strategy, service design, UX/UI, web and mobile development, communication and social media.
Through Forever, his family’s investment company, Giorgio Rossi Cairo is a partner in four other companies: [http://www.maus.it/en/default.asp Maus], a producer of automatic fettling, grinding and vertical turning machines; [http://www.ecornaturasi.it/en/ EcorNaturaSì], a leading distribution and retail company of organic food, [https://www.cmsantagostino.it/en Centro Medico Sant’Agostino], a health care services provider, and [http://www.corriere.it/economia/16_ottobre_16/italian-creation-group-acquisisce-fontana-arte-toscoquattro-83966f70-938f-11e6-b6f7-636834b27d39.shtml ItalianCreationGroup], an industrial holding that specializes in home design and luxury Italian lifestyle.
== External links == *[http://www.valuepartners.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/value-partners-171211-sfida-digitale-GRC-LEconomia-Corriere-della-Sera.pdf 18 buoni motivi per non perdere in treno digitale] L’Economia del Corriere della Sera, Federico De Rosa, 11 December 2017. *[http://www.gamberorosso.it/it/vini/1046224-l-arte-contemporanea-nelle-cantine-in-italia-un-rapporto-che-continua L’arte contemporanea nelle cantine italiane. Un rapporto che continua] Gambero Rosso, Loredana Sottile, 3 November 2017. *[http://www.fondazionelaraia.it/files/diconodinoi_file/2017/1705025_LaStampa.pdf Gavi, l'azienda agricola che fa arte tra i vigneti], La Stampa, Daniele Prato, 25 May 2017. * [http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/notizie/2017-05-03/vino-biodinamico-l-80percento-va-all-estero-162934.shtml?uuid=AEfoGeBB&fromSearch Vino biodinamico La Raia, l'80% va all'estero - Il Sole 24 Ore] Giorgio dell'Orefice, 3 May 2017. * [http://www.valuepartners.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/value-partners-161121-Exage-GRC-Corriere-Economia.pdf Industria 4.0 "Vi aiutiamo a fare la rivoluzione" - Corriere Economia] Greta Sclaunich, 21 November 2016. * [http://www.la-raia.it/news/parola-produttori Ecco cosa chiederei a Renzi] Il Sole 24Ore, 18 March 2015. * [http://www.valuepartners.com/downloads/PDF_Comunicati/value-partners-150307-grc_su_fibra-milanofinanza.pdf Fibra? Allacciatela come Google - MF] Gabriele Capolino, 7 March 2015. *[http://emanuelescarci.blog.ilsole24ore.com/2014/01/rossi-cairo-e-rosso-nel-capitale-di-ecornaturas%C3%AC.html Rossi Cairo e Rosso nel capitale di EcorNaturaSì], Il Sole 24Ore, Emanuele Scarci, 14 January 2014. * [http://www.valuepartners.com/downloads/PDF_Comunicati/value-partners-131118-interview_to_giorgio_rossi_cairo-international_business_daily(1).pdf China doesn’t understand much about Italy yet], International Business Daily, 13 November 2013. * [http://www.valuepartners.com/downloads/PDF_Comunicati/value-partners-130713-terzisti_grc-milanofinanza.pdf Un popolo di terzisti], Milano Finanza, Gabriele Capolino, 13 July 2013. * [http://www.valuepartners.com/downloads/PDF_Comunicati/value-partners-111205-concentrations-and-quality-low-costs-giorgio-rossi-cairo-correconomia(3).pdf Concentrations and quality low-costs: the most effective recipe for Italy to face current economic crisis], Corriere della Sera, Giorgio Rossi Cairo, 5 December 2011. *[http://www.valuepartners.com/downloads/PDF_Comunicati/value_partners__110618_the_brain_is_not_to_be_delocalized_giorgio_rossi_cairo_eng_milanofinanza.pdf The brain is not to be delocalized], MF, Gabriele Capolino, 18 June 2011. * [http://www.iese.edu/Aplicaciones/News/view.asp?id=2900&k=solutions_brain_drain_iese_alumni_event_milan_led_iese_prof_alberto_ribera Solutions for Brain Drain]. IESE Alumni Event in Milan led by IESE Prof. Alberto Ribera, Milano, Hotel Principe di Savoia, 19 maggio 2011. Giorgio Rossi Cairo takes part to the round table devoted to brain drain and Italian laws preventing it. * [http://www.valuepartners.com/downloads/PDF_Comunicati/Media%20e%20Eventi/2009/value-partners-rep_090720_interview_with_Giorgio_Rossi_Cairo_business_watch_magazine.pdf Multi 3G technology will be unified in the end], Business Watch Magazine, Zhou Yebin, 20 July 2009. *[http://www.unimib.it/upload/gestioneFiles/Symphonya/f2007issue1/rossicairoeng12007.pdf Trends in Strategic Consulting in the Face of Globalization], Università degli Studi Milano Bicocca, Symphonya. Emerging Issues in Management, 2007.

{{third-party|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox university | name = Hailey College of Banking and Finance, Lahore | image = | image_size = | caption = | established = 26 March 2003 | chancellor = | type = [[Education]] | city = [[Lahore]] | province = [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]] | campus = Urban | country = [[Pakistan]] | coor = {{coord|31|33|43|N|74|18|26.5|E|type:edu|display=inline,title}} | students = | postgrad = | faculty = | free_label = | free = | mascot = | affiliations=[[Higher Education Commission (Pakistan)|HEC]], [[University of the Punjab]] | website=[http://www.puhcbf.edu.pk/index.html/ www.puhcbf.edu.pk/index.html] }} '''Hailey College of Banking and Finance''' is a business school has an affiliation with [[University of the Punjab]] in Lahore.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Website|url=http://www.puhcbf.edu.pk/index.html|publisher=Hailey College of Banking and Finance|accessdate=2 October 2011}}</ref>
==History==
[[File:Hailey College of Banking and Finance.jpg|thumb|This is the front one sided view of Old Building of Hailey college of Banking and Finance]] Hailey College was emerged on 23 March 2003 by [[Khalid Maqbool]]. Hailey College of Banking and Finance has been established as the 5th Constituent College of the University of the Punjab, Lahore. College was inaugurated by Lt. Gen. (R) Khalid Maqbool (formerly Chancellor and Governor Punjab) on March 26, 2003. It is established in renovated old premises of [[Hailey College of Commerce]] which was shifted to Quaid-i-Azam (New) Campus, University of the Punjab in 1978.
The College is planning to start Certifications, Diplomas and Short Terms Courses to cater the need of the Trade, Commerce and Industry. Efforts are being made to develop entrepreneurship in the students so that they can undertake their own business work. Hailey college of banking and finance is more focusing on making entrepreneur rather than UN skill labour.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Website|url=http://www.puhcbf.edu.pk/index.html|publisher=Hailey College of Banking and Finance|accessdate=2 October 2011}}</ref>
==Programs== It provides following programs. * [[Bachelor of Business Administration]] * [[Master of Business Administration]]
'''These Degree Programs are offered in two different disciples''' * Banking and Finance <ref>"Official Website [http://www.puhcbf.edu.pk/acadamic.html]" Retrieved on 23-Jan-2014</ref> * Insurance and Risk Management <ref>"Official Website [http://www.puhcbf.edu.pk/acadamic.html]" Retrieved on 23-Jan-2014</ref>

'''Helmut Niedermeyer''' (28 February 1926 – 3 February 2014) was an Austrian businessman and entrepreneur. He founded [[Niedermeyer]], which was once the largest consumer electronics chain in Austria.
==Biography==
Niedermeyer was born in [[Opava]] in what is now the [[Czech Republic]]. His mother died shortly after his birth. His father, a successful cafe owner, served seven years in a Nazi [[concentration camp]]. Helmut Niedermeyer was a volunteer for the Soviets for five years. After the war, the family moved to [[Vienna]].<ref name=Kurier>{{cite news|title=Trauer um Helmut Niedermeyer|url=http://kurier.at/wirtschaft/unternehmen/trauer-um-helmut-niedermeyer-ein-kaufmann-vom-scheitel-bis-zur-sohle/49.766.105|accessdate=20 February 2014|newspaper=[[Kurier]]|date=4 February 2014|language=German|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508184039/http://kurier.at/wirtschaft/unternehmen/trauer-um-helmut-niedermeyer-ein-kaufmann-vom-scheitel-bis-zur-sohle/49.766.105|archivedate=8 May 2014|df=}}</ref>
He began his career as a salesman in 1949.<ref name=Kurier/> In 1957 he founded the company Niedermeyer AG as X-ray, photo and film products business. The company and its branches grew, and in the 1980s and 1990s became Niedermeyer-Konzem through various acquisitions. Niedermeyer retired from the board of the company in 1997. Two years later, it was sold to [[T-Mobile]] and changed ownership several times. It went bankrupt in 2013.<ref name=DiePresse>{{cite news|title=Unternehmer Helmut Niedermeyer gestorben|url=http://diepresse.com/home/wirtschaft/economist/1558385/Unternehmer-Helmut-Niedermeyer-gestorben|accessdate=17 February 2014|newspaper=[[Die Presse]]|date=4 February 2014|language=German}}</ref> He died on 3 February 2014 of a heart attack in [[Tenerife]], Spain. He is survived by his daughter, Angelika, and a son, Christian.<ref name=DiePresse/>
==References== {{reflist}}
